habitat: Mycorrhizal with hardwoods or conifers, growing alone or scattered in summer and fall. Widely distributed in North America.
shortDescription: Poisonous European native with a brownish fibrous cap, no ring, and contains muscarine.
benefitsOrToxicity: Contains muscarine. Serious poisoning can result from consuming any quantity of the mushroom.

identification.cap: 2-8 cm, conical to bell-shaped with a sharp bump. Dry, silky, straw yellow. Margin splits with age.
identification.stem: 3-9 cm long, up to 1 cm thick, equal. Dry, smooth, whitish or pale yellowish.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores 9.5-14.5 x 6-8.5 µ, elliptical, smooth. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia 30-65 x 10-22 µ.

note: Formerly Inocybe fastigiata. Contains muscarine. First described by Bulliard in 1789. The name means 'fibrous head' and 'full of cracks'.
